author: sky.cactus
content: Storing your own data is exactly what makes it decentralized.  If you want it, you have the ability to store it yourself however you want or outsource to whatever third party you want.  There is no entity or group that is compelled to store your data for you.

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, I do think there is value in a P2P data marketplace.  I just don't agree with your reasoning presented here.

author: sky.cactus
content: Transaction/receipt history encoded in a ZKProvable way would be rad.  That way you could ask anyone for a bit of history and validate it is authentic.  This would allow anyone to be a data provider and accept payment for history on a P2P data marketplace without needing to build trusted relationships.

author: kolbyml
content:
Have you heard of the Portal Network? Portal has a sub-network being built which will store all Ethereum mainnet history. All of the data will be validatable. Validating pre-merge blocks (the first 15,537,392 blocks) only requires the light client to store a 60.7 kB list of merkle roots.

The lightclients don't rely on full nodes for data instead each node stores the data closest to them. Light clients opt into how much storage they want to contribute to the network.

author: kolbyml
content: The Portal Network is a project with the initial goal of bringing a distributed Execution layer light clients into reality.

author: kolbyml
content: In short the Portal Network's is a collection of p2p networks with the goal of making an execution layer light client. Another way to phase it is  `Globally Available Highly Accessible Massively Cooperative Archive Node`. An execution layer archival node, not a consensus layer archival node at least yet

author: kolbyml
content:
Portal is not a generic storage network like IPFS (and I am assuming swarm?) Portal, IPFS, swarm all appear to use DHT tech but designed for different applications.

Portal is meant to store Ethereum mainnet data and only that. So we aren't a generic storage solution. We also are unique in that we take a validation first approach in our network (meaning everything being stored should be validatable that it is from the ethereum mainnet). Because of our constraints on what can be stored this gives us some advantages compared to just trying to store all of ethereum on IPFS.
